title: Unai Emery to talk to Arsenal hierarchy after Granit Xhaka appears to tell fans to 'f*** off'
text:
Unai Emery will hold talks with the Arsenal hierarchy before deciding whether Granit Xhaka will remain as club captain after he appeared to tell supporters to 'f*** off'.

Xhaka's fractious relationship with Gunners fans plummeted to new depths on Sunday after responding angrily to criticism from the home crowd as he was substituted.

After the draw against Crystal Palace, boss Emery on Sunday refused to guarantee that Xhaka will continue to wear the armband after admitting his key midfielder was wrong to react how he did.

Granit Xhaka was jeered off the pitch as Arsenal searched for a winner against Crystal Palace

Xhaka displayed his frustrations at the lack of support, appearing to tell fans to 'f*** off'

When directly asked whether Xhaka would remain captain, manager Emery replied: 'It's not the moment to speak about that because first I want to speak with him and the club.

'We need to stay calm but, really, he was wrong.'

Emery will hold crisis talks with his skipper on Monday, where he is likely to reprimand Xhaka.

The Switzerland international was already unpopular among a significant contingent of fans; Sunday's clash, in which he infuriated supporters with a series of antagonising gestures, will only serve to widen the disconnect between Xhaka and the Emirates faithful.

Emery refused to criticise Arsenal fans for sarcastically applauding and booing their captain - instead insisting Xhaka should have dealt with the situation with a cooler head.

The Arsenal skipper then cupped his hand to his ear as he was hauled off in the second half

Xhaka being subbed off pic.twitter.com/VIQsnhFBoC — Matt (@MGH) October 27, 2019

'We are working, me and the club to manage playing under pressure, when under pressure to have our minds clear,' said the Arsenal boss.

'In a difficult moment our heart can be hot, but our minds can be clever. We are going to speak about that because the reaction was wrong.

'We are going to speak (about that) inside, with the players and the club.

'We are here because we have supporters. We are the workers inside the club but we play for them.

'We need to have a lot of respect for them when they are applauding us but also when they are criticising us.'

Emery also blasted the decision to disallow what would have been a late winner for the Gunners via VAR.

Sokratis rammed home a loose ball to spark wild celebrations, but the goal was eventually ruled out because of a foul from Callum Chambers on Luka Milivojevic.

Arsenal boss Unai Emery admitted the skipper was wrong after the final whistle

But replays show the tangle between Chambers on Milivojevic was far from clear-cut, and Emery added: 'Our goal, the third goal, he is not fouled. That is not a foul. Who is the person who checked that? If the referee watched that action on the TV, I am sure he would not decide that it was a foul.

'In the office with the TV, I don't know who the person is who decides this. (For the referee to view a screen on the side of the pitch) is the next step. We lost two points to that tonight. The next step is that they will check. We have cameras on the pitch, but here I don't remember a single referee going to check on the touchline. I don't remember that.

'VAR is to help the referees, but also to watch or to take the best decision with your own eyes.'

Xhaka took his shirt off in frustration as left the pitch during the Premier League clash

Palace boss Roy Hodgson also had to deal with a show of indiscipline from one of his players; Jordan Ayew visibly furious after being replaced by Christian Benteke during the closing stages.

Hodgson added: 'I didn't notice particularly, but I would suspect players don't like coming off the field. But often afterwards, after they have settled down they feel it was the right decision.

'I thought the fresh legs was a good idea, and I'm sure if you asked Jordan he would agree with you.

'But if he was upset, I don't hold that against him. I'm really quite pleased. I don't want them to be happy about coming off, I want them to want to stay on the field.'
description: SAMI MOKBEL AT THE EMIRATES STADIUM: Unai Emery will hold talks with the Arsenal hierarchy before deciding whether Granit Xhaka will remain as captain.
authors: Sami Mokbel For The Daily Mail
